canonical_explanation.text: Two triangles are similar if their corresponding angles are equal and their corresponding sides are in proportion. The criteria for similarity are: (1) AA (Angle-Angle): If two angles of one triangle are equal to two angles of another triangle, the triangles are similar. (2) SAS (Side-Angle-Side): If one angle of a triangle is equal to one angle of another triangle and the sides including these angles are proportional, the triangles are similar. (3) SSS (Side-Side-Side): If the corresponding sides of two triangles are proportional, the triangles are similar. Basic Proportionality Theorem (BPT/Thales' Theorem): If a line is drawn parallel to one side of a triangle intersecting the other two sides, it divides those sides in the same ratio. The converse is also true: if a line divides two sides of a triangle in the same ratio, it is parallel to the third side. For similar triangles, the ratio of their areas equals the square of the ratio of their corresponding sides.
rules: AA Criterion: Two triangles are similar if two angles of one triangle are equal to two angles of another
SAS Criterion: Two triangles are similar if one angle is equal and the sides including that angle are proportional
SSS Criterion: Two triangles are similar if all corresponding sides are proportional
BPT (Thales' Theorem): A line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two sides proportionally
Converse of BPT: If a line divides two sides of a triangle proportionally, it is parallel to the third side
Ratio of areas of similar triangles = (ratio of corresponding sides)²
In similar triangles, corresponding angles are equal and corresponding sides are proportional
The symbol ~ denotes similarity between triangles
